title.value: Learning the Game: Decoding the Differences Between Novice and Expert Players in a Citizen Science Game With Millions of Players
title.justification: The title was explicitly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Learning the Game: Decoding the Differences Between Novice and Expert Players in a Citizen Science Game With Millions of Players

extractions.description: This paper analyzes the strategies of novice and expert players in the citizen science game Borderlands Science (BLS) to understand their actions and outcomes. It uses a Markov chain model trained on player solutions to investigate strategic differences and how they evolve as players gain experience.

type.justification: The paper involves empirical analysis by collecting and analyzing data from player actions in the game BLS to understand and model their strategies.
type.quote: Our findings reveal distinct and evolving player strategies. For future citizen science projects, it will be important to consider the identification of player strategies and their evolution over time to improve the game design and data processing.

name.justification: The paper focuses on citizen science games as a tool for solving computational tasks using human participation.
name.quote: Citizen science games (CSGs) leverage the processing power of gamers to solve computational and scientific problems.

name.justification: The paper utilizes the concept of multiple sequence alignment (MSA) problems which are translated into puzzles within the game Borderlands Science.
name.quote: Multiple sequence alignment (MSA) is a fundamental problem in bioinformatics that aims to identify conserved regions and functional domains across multiple related sequences.

name.justification: The research involves analyzing player behavior and strategies within a game setup, making it relevant to the field of Game Design.
name.quote: In this study, we explore the potential of citizen science games as a MSA solving tool.

name.justification: The research involves developing a Markov chain model to understand player actions and outcomes based on solutions from players with different levels of experience.
name.quote: We developed a Markov chain trained on solutions from players of different experience levels to understand their actions and outcomes.

is_contributed.justification: The paper contributed a Markov chain model specifically for analyzing the data collected from the BLS game.
is_contributed.quote: We developed a Markov chain trained on solutions from players of different experience levels to understand their actions and outcomes.

is_executed.justification: The Markov chain model was executed to analyze player behavior and strategies.
is_executed.quote: In a Markov chain, the transition probability matrix defines the probability of moving from one state to another, given the current state. The transition probabilities are estimated from a set of observed sequences.

is_compared.justification: The model was not compared with other models in the paper.
is_compared.quote: To analyze the player behaviours in BLS, we created a Markov Chain model with the 5 player actions, as well as the start of the game and the end of the game.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper title associated with the model.

name.justification: The paper utilized data from player solutions in the BLS game for analysis and model training.
name.quote: The data used in our study was obtained from the BLS game, which is based on human gut microbe genome fragments pre-aligned with PASTA.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This dataset does not have a dedicated paper reference, it was collected as part of the game analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The data used in our study was obtained from the BLS game, which is based on human gut microbe genome fragments pre-aligned with PASTA.
